nodes.text: An ultra-fast GPU error-bounded lossy compressor (cuSZp) that performs all compression and decompression inside a single GPU kernel can achieve substantially higher end-to-end throughput while maintaining high compression ratios and high reconstructed data quality for scientific HPC datasets.
Design cuSZp as a single-kernel GPU compressor to eliminate CPU-GPU data movement and kernel-launch overheads, making end-to-end throughput equal to kernel throughput.

Use a block-wise pipeline composed of four steps: (S1) Quantization and Prediction, (S2) Fixed-length Encoding, (S3) Global Synchronization, and (S4) Block Bit-shuffle, applied per-block to enable parallelism and high compression ratio.

Quantization and Prediction: pre-quantize floating-point to integers (bounded by error bound) then apply lightweight 1D 1-layer Lorenzo prediction inside each block to reduce bit entropy; this is the only lossy step.

Fixed-length Encoding per block: record sign map, compute max absolute quantized integer to determine a fixed number of bits F_k for the block, and store (F_k+1)*L/8 bytes for that block instead of variable-length codes.

Hierarchical Global Synchronization implemented entirely on GPU as an exclusive prefix-sum (thread-level, warp-level, global-level) to compute per-block compressed offsets and final compressed size without CPU intervention.

Block Bit-shuffle: rearrange bits of fixed-length encoded integers into aligned bytes by bit-offset across block elements to enable efficient parallel writing to global memory and avoid irregular bit shifting.

End-to-end throughput result: cuSZp achieves average end-to-end compression/decompression of 93.63 GB/s and 120.04 GB/s and speeds up end-to-end performance by 95.53x over cuSZ and 55.18x over cuSZx on NVIDIA A100 across six representative datasets.

Kernel throughput result: cuSZp kernel throughput is inline/comparable (~100 GB/s or higher) with state-of-the-art GPU lossy compressors including cuZFP and cuSZx; single-kernel design makes kernel and end-to-end throughputs equal.

Compression ratio result: cuSZp attains the highest compression ratio in 16 of 24 evaluated cases (various datasets and error bounds), often exceeding cuSZ and cuSZx while maintaining single-kernel constraints.

Data quality result: cuSZp preserves high reconstructed data fidelity (higher PSNR and SSIM vs cuZFP in many fields) and yields better visualization (fewer artifacts) than cuZFP and cuSZx under comparable compression settings.

Evidence: Global Synchronization microbenchmark achieves on average 208.06 GB/s throughput on A100 (range 120.5â€“260.8 GB/s across datasets), validating the hierarchical in-kernel prefix-sum implementation.

Assumption: Scientific datasets exhibit high local smoothness inside short blocks (L small), making fixed-length per-block encoding effective and limiting the benefit of per-block Huffman or variable-length encoders.

Limitation and future work: current evaluation uses NVIDIA GPUs (A100, V100, RTX 3080) and CUDA; performance depends on GPU memory bandwidth and block tuning; future work includes exploiting newer GPU architectures and integrating cuSZp into live simulations.
